nodes.text: Counties causally affect children's adult incomes and specific county characteristics explain variation in intergenerational mobility, implying places matter for economic opportunity
We estimate county-level causal effects on children's income ranks at age 26 using a movers-based fixed-effects exposure-time design and administrative tax data for 1980–1986 birth cohorts

Identification: regress child outcome on origin-by-destination fixed effects and years of childhood exposure to each place; key assumption is exposure timing orthogonal to potential outcomes conditional on origin-destination
Validation: placebo tests (moves after age 23, labor force participation at age 16) and controls for parental income and marital status support orthogonality and robustness of estimates

Magnitude: for children with parents at the 25th percentile, one year in a one standard deviation better county raises adult household income by ~0.5% (0.17 percentile points); 20 years from birth implies ~10% gain

Heterogeneity: place effects are larger for boys than girls (about 60% larger dispersion for boys at p=25); effects similar in percentile/dollar terms for high-income families but smaller in percent terms
There is substantial spatial variation: counties within the same commuting zone differ materially; some counties are 'opportunity bargains' with high causal effects but low rents

Signal/noise decomposition: estimated raw SD of county fixed effects contains large sampling noise; after adjustment the signal SD across counties at p=25 is 0.165 (annual) implying meaningful but modest place variance
Forecasting method: construct MSE-minimizing forecasts by optimally shrinking movers-based fixed effects toward permanent-resident outcomes using their signal-to-noise ratio

Predictors: county/CZ characteristics such as less residential segregation, lower income inequality, better school outcomes, more social capital, and higher share of two-parent families are positively associated with causal effects for low-income children

Causal vs sorting decomposition: for many area-level predictors (e.g., segregation, school quality, social capital) most of the observational correlation with mobility is due to causal place effects; for demographic aggregates (single mothers, racial composition, immigrant share) selection explains a larger fraction

Housing capitalization and policy implication: within CZs rents weakly correlate with causal effects (rents explain <5% county variance in μ for p=25 in large CZs), implying many affordable opportunity bargains and that rent-based voucher rules may not target high-opportunity places
